commit 193a60541f4e10ce53158983fb7a9e93bb9d8d78
Author: Karthik Kambatla <kasha@apache.org>
Date:   Sun Feb 26 20:16:36 2017 -0800

    YARN-6215. Custom Cloudera version. FairScheduler preemption and update should not run concurrently. (Tao Jie via kasha)
    
    C5.x (based on 2.6.0) FairScheduler locking is through synchroization on the scheduler object. Upstram (2.9.0+) uses separate read and write locks.
    Accordingly, this commit applies YARN-6215 in principle: performs the preemption code under the same lock as the scheduler uses to run update.
    
    (cherry picked from commit 815d53506fb0c5ca029c993d6b094db2ac0ca6eb)
    (cherry picked from commit a95d3e1fe7d533990be305e6cf1d10c8c512908b)
    
    Change-Id: If8006a6f5aef6eadcbd348caa2a0cd54354524a0

commit db090dc85c2aa117de4527b71447b8cbe4a20ba2
Author: Karthik Kambatla <kasha@apache.org>
Date:   Fri Jan 27 10:38:57 2017 -0800

    YARN-4752. Improved preemption in FairScheduler. (kasha)
    
    The backport was done manually by copying changes from YARN-4752, because they were too many conflicts due to locking and node-labeling changes. Notable differences are:
    * FSLeafQueue#assignContainer is now more in line with upstream, capturing apps with demand in a TreeSet instead of explicit sorting.
    * RMContainerImpl now implements Comparable; upstream, this was introduced in YARN-2498 (CS preemption and node labels).
    * TestFairScheduler - a couple of tests needed adding scheduler.update() after submitting an application.
    * More tests deleted from TestFSLeafQueue; upstream, the same were in TestFairSchedulerPreemption.
    
    Change-Id: I54b92b8fd206b2d7cfc0dc163301348e9081b3fd

Author: Steve Loughran <stevel@apache.org>

commit f719cc284ca8e70b34ad8ca9e1a5293cea5241ba
Author: Manoj Govindassamy <manojg@cloudera.com>
Date:   Thu Jan 12 11:01:30 2017 -0800

    CLOUDERA-BUILD. CDH-37372 Change DataNode logging level for slow BlockReceiver actions
    
    BlockReceiver logs a WARN message for every IO operations relating to flush,
    sync, write to mirror, write to disk, ack upstream that are taking more than
    300ms. These slowness are generally seen in a cluster under heavy load. In
    the past these WARN messages had led to several support calls and only
    asked to be ignored in an otherwise healthy cluster.
    
    Change-Id: I86b4bdee4e96c91c926d01f9cc9392f647a858be

commit 9859e53e49f9b934f649289dada9109e6a7b4399
Author: Aaron Fabbri <fabbri@cloudera.com>
Date:   Wed May 25 21:01:57 2016 -0700

    IMPALA-2607 CLOUDERA-BUILD S3: need to determine the right default for fs.s3a.connection.maximum
    
    Increase fs.s3a.connection.maximum config default from 15 to 100 TCP
    connections.  This allows applications like Impala to keep more files (input
    streams) open at a time.
    
    Based on discussion with Impala devs, there isn't a real upper bound on number
    of files open per-impala process.   It sounds like there is no real upper bound
    on the number of open files (and thus connections from s3a's underlying Apache
    httpclient connection pool).
    
    Change-Id: If7a588dd9e1ba96de2b5e1def701fde3554f8c4b

commit f561c226682d2aef39dd6e99b5296428c6e4f46c
Author: Aaron Fabbri <fabbri@cloudera.com>
Date:   Wed May 25 20:57:49 2016 -0700

    CDH-24695 CLOUDERA-BUILD Copying a local file to s3 via hdfs cli is slow
    
    Change multipart upload parameters so the feature actually gets used.
    
    - Multipart threshold 2GB -> 16MB
    - Multipart size 100MB -> 8MB
    
    New values based on testing and comparing to what AWS CLI does today.
    
    Change-Id: I18247b784c3ca593c977453c83f7c0a07d4bc143

commit 2b855a685a8dd445c9e20139967b4c16aab3df12
Author: Mani Narayan <mnarayan@cloudera.com>
Date:   Fri Apr 8 14:57:41 2016 -0700

    CLOUDERA-BUILD: Downloading apache tomcat from archive.cloudera.com
    
    archive.apache.org has blacklisted Cloudera's build workers on ec2, and
    fetching artifacts from there fails. The artifact that Hadoop relies on is apache-tomcat,
    and this has been moved to archive.cloudera.com. This change simply
    updates pom.xml to point to archive.cloudera.com
    
    For more information:
    https://jira.cloudera.com/browse/RELENG-281.
    
    Testing done:
    Generated effetive pom.xml, and verified that the url points to
    http://mirror.infra.cloudera.com/apache/tomcat/tomcat-6/v6.0.44/bin/apache-tomcat-6.0.44.tar.gz
    Will also build locally to verify that builds work, and update the
    review once done.
    
    Change-Id: I6c344da432f453416b41aa84674875f9d26bf653
    (cherry picked from commit ba807c8c04b8f000d15540a382a9f7fbed539296)
    (cherry picked from commit 02e41f13fcf5cd5cea97491b0af1484ba5de2675)

commit 99367b2ee4d16a4b697f3d80f1dfdc13c78440d2
Author: Karthik Kambatla <kasha@apache.org>
Date:   Wed Mar 16 15:10:58 2016 -0700

    CLOUDERA-BUILD. CDH-38435. MR rolling upgrade breaks due to security fix introduced in CDH-27001.
    
    More details:
    - CDH-27001 fixes a security issue that concerns storing the key used to encrypt
      spill data alongside the spill itself. The fix here was to send this key from
      AM to Task over Hadoop RPC. Since it is not versioned, this leads to an
      incompatibility and breaks rolling upgrade.
    - In CDH-38435, we fix this by reusing extraData, which was originally
      introduced to run MR1 on Mesos, for storing this key instead of serializing it
      separately. Both extraData and setExtraData are non-public methods in a
      @Private @Unstable class, and we are not obligated to support it.
    
    Testing:
    - To test this fix, we ran a cluster with two nodes using 5.5.0 bits and 1 node
      using these bits. We were successfully able to run jobs with AM running 5.5.0
      and AM running 5.7.0. And, a job with the intermediate data encrypted.
    
    Change-Id: I3567e26272fd854fc8253f1e998f21da6bfb9cef

commit 453442a736a2ee938a48dcd22c0b62dcfc085d82
Author: Philip Zeyliger <philip@cloudera.com>
Date:   Tue Dec 15 20:45:43 2015 +0000

    CLOUDERA-BUILD Exposing maven variables to ant
    
    Reason: New Feature
    Author: Philip Zeyliger
    Ref: CDH-34616
    
    To make repository.cloudera.com configurable,
    it's necessary to expose Maven variables to
    ant. This was already being done to an extent,
    with ant calling 'mvn process-resources',
    and a custom Maven plugin (com.cloudera.kitchen.maven-deps-to-props-plugin)
    materializing a file with assorted CDH component and
    dependency versions.  This approach, however,
    did not immediately let me materialize
    a Maven property, nor did I wish to use "mvn help:evaluate",
    which is awkward and hard-to-parse.
    
    Instead, I use Maven's standard "maven-resources-plugin"
    to capture the variables I need.  More to the point,
    once I'm using that, I can actually port over the existing
    dependency version stuff straight to this built-in plugin,
    reducing our world's plugin footprint by one.
    
    I did the same thing in the Solr build earlier,
    and it worked there.
    
    To verify this, I simply ran diff.  Very astute readers
    will notice that https://repository used to be https\://repository.
    My reading of http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/Properties.html#load(java.io.Reader) as well as experimentation suggests
    that it's not strictly necessary to escape that colon, and it works
    fine, so I've left it.  (The new lines are ugly because I sorted
    the input; they're nicely spaced in the real output.)
    
        $diff -u <(cat /mnt/philip/cdh2/repos/cdh5/hadoop/hadoop-mapreduce1-project/build.properties | sed -e s,5.7.0,5.7.6, | sort | uniq) <(cat build.p
        roperties | sort | uniq)
        --- /dev/fd/63  2015-12-15 20:46:44.531193170 +0000
        +++ /dev/fd/62  2015-12-15 20:46:44.531193171 +0000
        @@ -1,10 +1,20 @@
        -#
        +
         avro.version=1.7.6-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT
        +# Default reactor.repo for developer builds.
        +# Defined canonically in the CDH root pom,
        +# do-component-build with the local .m2 repository.
         hadoop-common.version=2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT
         hadoop-hdfs.version=2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT
         hadoop-mapreduce.version=2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT
         hadoop.version=2.6.0-mr1-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT
        -reactor.repo=https\://repository.cloudera.com/content/repositories/snapshots
        -#Tue Dec 15 20:30:15 UTC 2015
        +# Pakaging builds tend to override this in
        +reactor.repo=https://repository.cloudera.com/content/repositories/snapshots
        +releases.cloudera.com=file:///mnt/philip/local-repository/cdh-staging-local/
        +repository.root=file:///mnt/philip/local-repository
        +snapshots.cloudera.com=file:///mnt/philip/local-repository/cdh-snapshot-local/
        +# The default (at last check) is http://maven.jenkins.cloudera.com:8081/artifactory
        +# These override the settings in ivysettings.xml
        +# this may be overridden by ~/.m2/settings.xml.
         version=2.6.0-mr1-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT
        +# Versions from root CDH pom.xml
         zookeeper.version=3.4.5-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT
    
    Change-Id: I473e31c422594dce62641e09baaa18f761a4141a

commit a0bcb7a09ab664210e00393a32075b36bb5f1dd7
Author: Aaron Fabbri <fabbri@cloudera.com>
Date:   Mon Dec 7 14:13:02 2015 -0800

    CPLAT-656 hadoop-aws shades old version of Joda-time, breaking S3A
    
    The cdh parent pom hard-codes an old version of joda-time, which was overriding
    the correct version required by the updated version of the aws-java-sdk-s3.
    
    Fix is to explicly specify the joda-time dependency with the version the current
    aws-java-sdk-s3 expects.
    
    This patch also fixes CDH-31245.

commit 11001f7a2060e9662983df9dbe67a4a7f8045fa7
Author: Philip Zeyliger <philip@cloudera.com>
Date:   Fri Nov 20 19:43:41 2015 +0000

    CLOUDERA-BUILD Specify assembly artifact naming.
    
    Reason: New Feature
    Author: Philip Zeyliger
    Ref: CDH-34616
    
    When using SNAPSHOT artifacts, there are two names
    for an hbase jar.  For example,
      hbase-server-1.0.0-cdh5.7.6-20151201.205646-1.jar (stored in
      org/apache/hbase/hbase-server/1.0.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT in a maven repo)
    or
      hbase-server-1.0.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT.jar
    
    Depending on whether you're using the local ~/.m2/repository or a "remote"
    file:// repository (and equivalently using "mvn install" vs "mvn deploy"), the
    assembly gets different names.  Our world expects the -SNAPSHOT name, and fails
    subtly if it doesn't happen.
    
    The suble error you'd see would be something like this from
    the RPM build:
    
        [DEBUG] adding entry hadoop-2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT/share/hadoop/mapreduce/sources/hadoop-mapreduce-client-app-2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT-sources.jar
        ...
        [DEBUG] adding entry hadoop-2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT/share/hadoop/mapreduce/hadoop-mapreduce-client-app-2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-20151120.212535-3.jar
        ...
        + '[' -e /mnt/philip/cdh-trunk/build/cdh5/hadoop/2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT/rpm/BUILDROOT/hadoop-2.6.0+cdh5.7.6+981-1.cdh5.7.6.p0.el6.x86_64/usr/lib/hadoop-mapreduce//hadoop-mapreduce-client-app-2.6.0-cdh5.7.6-SNAPSHOT.jar ']'
        + exit 1
    
    (Those DEBUG lines were created by adding -X to the mvn invocation in do-component-build,
    which was how I got to the bottom of it.)
    
    This very small XML change makes that error go away.
    
    Other people have experienced this at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MASSEMBLY-67.
    
    Change-Id: I3dd47f2c558fd9914ea6f3389e5f0684a16a338f

commit 77d25b45d3b6abea8fd0f7a9ba64bc32162c61f4
Author: Mike Yoder <myoder@cloudera.com>
Date:   Tue Nov 3 14:35:25 2015 -0800

    CLOUDERA-BUILD. CDH-33705. HttpFS Keystore password exposed on cmd line
    
    The keystore password for httpfs was placed into $CATALINA_OPTS, which
    ultimately makes its way to the command line as Tomcat starts up. This
    changes things so that if CATALINA_BASE (the environment variable
    describing where Catalina config information is located) exists, and
    the catalina.properties file exists, then the appropriate config
    entries are written into the catalina.properties file. Information
    placed in that file goes into Tomcat just like the environment
    variable does.
    
    Change-Id: I7dfdc99fe6fbdbbec4ce04a6d46ad97d52eb6381

commit bac1a2a0dd7d3662f8d781542e7ffee5ec36a61d
Author: Aaron Fabbri <fabbri@cloudera.com>
Date:   Thu Jul 16 15:10:37 2015 -0700

    CDH-29426 CDH-29525 distcp to s3a fails due to integer overflow..
    
    Build fixes for newer AWS SDK.
    
    Fix classpath shading for joda-time.
    
    Excluding joda-time from the aws-java-sdk dependency breaks with newer versions
    of the aws sdk.
    
    In fact, the previous maven shading config was broken, because the shading
    relocation does nothing if that artifact is not a dependency.
    
    This commit adds the joda time classes to the uber/shaded jar, and adds
    depenency exclusions for the parent artifacts that depend on this one.
    
    Change-Id: Iea44f29578dacf0e577c3b235628b5823b6ae7f1

commit 073fffec79bc0271bd1631057a585f9ef08fbd0a
Author: Gilad Wolff <gilad@cloudera.com>
Date:   Tue Jan 21 14:35:48 2014 -0800

    MR1: CLOUDERA-BUILD. Preliminary version of MAPREDUCE-5707. ApplicationClientProtocolPBClientImpl (and JobClient) does not allow to set rpcTimeout
    
    This commit adds the ability to enable rpc timeout for the job client.
    The approach taken was to add a new configuration parameter
    "mapreduce.jobclient.rpc.timeout". By default it is set to -1 (no
    timeout) to maintain backword compatibility. If set to some positive
    integer it will be used as the rpcTimeout in the underlying ipc Client.
    
    Testing done: New unit-tests. TestRpcTimeout hanged forever before
    this commit and now passes.
    (cherry-picked from commit 3167c63e253e502b16cfb27079d3bd825e96f4be)
    
    (cherry picked from commit 7901f25f833a93b17fb079e94f4f8ac57ee060d8)
    (cherry picked from commit 731cc2c0543f8182f8f834db01e2a8af3bc99c99)
    
    Conflicts:
    	hadoop-mapreduce1-project/src/mapred/org/apache/hadoop/mapred/JobTrackerProxies.java
